primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God intervenes in human history through the Word of the prophet to bring the sinner to repentance, thereby enabling restoration and redemption.

subject.identificatie: God / The Word of the Lord
tekstueel_bewijs: God’s continual overriding of our failures to accomplish his purpose
Human frailty cannot prevent God from recapturing the world
The word of the Lord came to Elijah
God’s judgment is an instrument of his mercy

object.identificatie: Redemption / New Life / Recapturing the world
tekstueel_bewijs: royal road to redemption and new life
recapturing the world that he loves

zender.identificatie: God (as Source of Truth and Mercy)
tekstueel_bewijs: the Father kept all his promises
So, fellow bad characters, there is absolutely nothing that you can do that is so terrible that God cannot overcome it.

helper.identificatie: The Prophet (Nathan/Elijah/Jeremiah) / The Word / Jesus Christ
tekstueel_bewijs: Nathan said to David, Thou art the man
the Lord Jesus Christ himself was called the Son of David

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin / Human Frailty / False Prophets (Access-seekers) / Pride
tekstueel_bewijs: David, like various presidents... contrives to cover up his sin
preachers withhold the word of accountability in order to preserve access
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Sin is presented not just as a mistake but as a 'sordid mess' that requires divine intervention to 'overcome' and 'recapture'.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The human response of confession and repentance as the 'royal road' to the primary program's goal.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Hearer / David
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The secondary program (human response) is triggered by the primary program (God's judgment/mercy via the prophet).

voorbeelden_god_subject: God’s continual overriding of our failures
Human frailty cannot prevent God from recapturing the world
God’s judgment is an instrument of his mercy
voorbeelden_mens_subject: The man who can acknowledge his sin
We wish this had not happened
David promptly arranges to marry Bathsheba

voorbeelden: We wish this had never come to light
discerning the sin that lies embedded there
nothing that you can do that is so terrible that God cannot overcome it

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon focuses on the 'Power' (Pouvoir) of God to overcome sin, contrasting it with the false power of political access.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Moves from the silence of churches (~S2) to the necessity of Judgment (S2) as the only vehicle to reach true Mercy (S1).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Judgment is redefined as an 'instrument of mercy,' resolving the tension between S1 and S2.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High; judgment is presented as essential for salvation.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: While the sermon calls for human action (confession), it frames this action as a response to God's prior and overriding initiative. God is the primary actor who 'recaptures' and 'overcomes'.

indicatoren_moralisme.indicator: Focus on human capacity for strength
indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: It is not a weakness to acknowledge that one has been wrong; it is a sign of strength.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: Human frailty cannot prevent God from recapturing the world that he loves.
His purpose toward you is unconditionally loving. That is the foundation on which we stand.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: David is used as an example, but specifically as an example of a 'bad character' whom God uses and who responds to God's initiative.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already leans theocentric by emphasizing God's use of 'bad characters'.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and security coupled with a call to honesty.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Justification by grace through faith, including the 'simul iustus et peccator' reality.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from political commentary to biblical narrative to personal application is seamless and structurally consistent.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'strength' in confession and 'powerlessness' before God.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: coming before the throne of God without defenses... in the secure knowledge that the Father kept all his promises

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Word acts as the external endowment of competence (Savoir/Pouvoir).

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Severe; sin is a 'sordid mess' that requires divine confrontation.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully maintains God as the Subject of the primary narrative program (Salvation/Recapturing), while placing the human in the role of Receiver.

identificatie_herstel.problematische_identificatie: The hearer might identify with the 'strength' of David's confession rather than the 'mercy' of God's initiative.
identificatie_herstel.voorgestelde_identificatie: The 'poor man' with the lamb (Receiver of injustice/mercy).
identificatie_herstel.strategie: Emphasize that even the 'strength' to confess is a gift of the Spirit.

modale_balans.huidige_onbalans: Slightly high on Devoir (Must confess) at the end.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Explicitly state that God's grace gives us the power to blush again.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: A masterful example of using a 'Heavy Opponent' (Sin) to highlight the 'Supreme Subject' (God) without falling into moralism.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: Rhetorical analysis would focus on the use of the Clinton anecdote; Greimas reveals that the anecdote serves as a 'Negative Sender' (Worldly values) contrasted with the 'Divine Sender'.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains David's sin; Greimas shows that David is an actant (Receiver) in a larger program of God's 'recapturing'.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that 'Access' is the false Object of the Opponent, while 'Redemption' is the true Object of the Subject (God).

appendices.notities: The sermon avoids moralism by making the 'act of confession' a response to a 'divine confrontation' rather than a self-generated work.
